subject: Creativity
title: Hemingway's Iceberg: Writing Less to Say More
description: A tiny lesson with a big payoff: Hemingway's Iceberg: Writing Less to Say More.

hook.text: Hemingway wrote a complete story in six words: 'For sale: baby shoes, never worn.' Six words. An entire tragedy.

buildup.text: His iceberg theory: the writer knows the full story. The reader sees only 1/8 above the surface.

discovery.text: He achieved this through radical cutting. His first drafts were long.

twist.text: He wrote standing up, using a pencil, and stopped each day mid-sentence ‚Äî so he'd know exactly where to start tomorrow.

climax.text: The Old Man and the Sea was originally 300 pages. He cut it to 127.

punchline.text: Great writing isn't adding words. It's knowing which ones to remove.

quiz.question: How did Hemingway ensure he could easily resume writing each day?
